author: Kevin Kernan
title: Joe Maddon has Cubs pitching trick up sleeve for NLCS
text:
CHICAGO – The Wild Card Cubs are holding all the aces for the NLCS.
Just the way Joe Maddon likes it.
By finishing off the Cardinals Tuesday night at Wrigley Field, Maddon’s club has set itself up perfectly for the NLCS – either going east or west for the first two games of the series against the Mets or Dodgers, two teams pushed to the cross-country limit by their five-game NLDS.
After beating the Cardinals 6-4 to clinch a postseason series at home for the first time in franchise history and partying hard — the clubhouse essentially became a nightclub, strobe lights and all — the Cubs rested Wednesday and await Thursday’s result between the Mets and Dodgers in LA with Jacob deGrom going against Zack Greinke.
The Cubs will get back to work Thursday with a light workout in preparation for Saturday’s Game 1, but they will have three days of rest after going hard since the Wild Card game, a 4-0 win over the Pirates.
This is a team that rarely takes on-field batting practice, so they have been planning for the long haul for a while.
The biggest plus is the Cubs’ pitching is set up perfectly while the Mets and Dodgers have had to use their top weapons twice.
Maddon will have his two aces ready for Games 1 and 2 of the NLCS: Jake Arrieta and Jon Lester. He is likely to go with the left-hander Lester in Game 1 and Arrieta in Game 2, simply because the innings are piling up on Arrieta like never before and in his last outing he was not nearly as sharp as he has been. Lester will have had seven days’ rest if he pitches Saturday.
Arrieta has thrown 67 more innings this season than any previous year in his career, and there are possibly two seven-game series to go.
Lester is the Cubs’ $155 million man and would relish a Game 1 start in the NLCS, but said he would have no issues starting the second game.
Your browser does not support iframes. Shortstop Addison Russell missed Game 4 because of a hamstring injury and will get three extra days of therapy to see if he will be ready to go. If not, backup Javier Baez — who blasted a three-run homer Tuesday night — gets the nod.
Maddon has all his young weapons clicking, especially rookie slugger Kyle Schwarber and first baseman Anthony Rizzo. The Cubs hit nine home runs the two games at Wrigley and have a decided home-field advantage.
It's official: @Cubs verify that this is @kschwarb12 's home run ball: http://t.co/0nHARR9SR6 pic.twitter.com/BVUoDEuOQ6 
— WGN TV News (@WGNNews) October 14, 2015 

Knowing if they can get a split in the first two games on the road, they can close out the series in three straight games in Wrigley is a wonderful position for this talented team.
Asked who will be the next hero for the Cubs, Maddon said during the victory celebration: “Stay tuned, man. They’ve all been playing, they are all part of the ownership group here. That’s the way it should be. I did visualize this, I’ve already visualized the next step. We’ll see how it all plays out, but you’ve got to be a little bit of a dreamer to make it all come true.’’
Keep dreaming. Everything is coming up aces for Maddon and his Wild Card Cubs.
